dataset.title: The games plants play: the defensive strategies of Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis with respect to the interaction between elephants and fire

individualName.surName: Anna Chu, Susan Lin, Jenn Mizen, Laurence Kruger (resource person)

abstract.para: African savannas are shaped by the interaction of two ecological factors: African elephants (Loxodonta africana) and fires. The response of individual Acacias to megaherbivores and fire regimes is dependent on their life history strategies. The resulting architecture of trees is a trade-off between a strategy of growing tall to escape low-lying fires or of developing thick, insulating bark to protect the internal structure from heat damage. Allometric studies suggest that there is a strong relationship between trunk diameter and average bark thickness, as well as trunk diameter and height, in Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis. When both have similar bark thicknesses, A. nigrescens tends to grow taller and burn at higher temperatures than A. tortilis. The combination of bark stripping and field burns show that elephants can have dramatic effects on the survival abilities of trees during fires and that Acacias have varied life history strategies in response. Severely debarked (over 50%) A. nigrescens have greater odds of experiencing interruptions in the water column, as reflected in increased leaf discoloration and wilting, whereas A. tortilis shows no effect within the same time period. This suggests that A. nigrescens copes with fire and megafaunal herbivory by increasing canopy height and A. tortilis copes by investing in bark with greater insular ability to protect against fire and in mechanical defences to protect against herbivory.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Leokwe Camp, Magunpubwe National Park, Limpopo Province, South Africa

section.para: Mapungubwe National Park (S22.21850 E029.36489) is a xeric savanna with a diverse
array of flora and fauna, situated in the Limpopo Province of South Africa on the borders
of Botswana and Zimbabwe. Our experiment took place over the span of six days from
13-18 November 2006. We burned and collected tree samples from four sites around
Leokwe Camp in Mapungubwe National Park.
Study Species
We performed our allometry study, field burn experiment and burn temperature study
on Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis. A. nigrescens occurs from KwaZulu-Natal in
South Africa northward into central Africa (Schmidt et al. 2002). In response to
herbivory, A. nigrescens has both mechanical and chemical defense. The bark of A.
nigrescens is covered with thorn-tipped knobs and rich with tannin. Similarly, A. tortilis
is widespread throughout the bushveld biomes of South Africa with distribution ranging
from the Northern Cape northward to the Limpopo Province and westward to
Mpumalanga (Schmidt et al. 2002). A. tortilis is characterized by a combination of
mechanical defenses manifested as hooks and thorns.
Allometry
Acacia tortilis versus Acacia nigrescens. Trunk diameter, average bark thickness and
height data were taken from 27 A. nigrescens and 29 A. tortilis near the Leokwe camp.
Individuals were chosen to represent a range of size classes. Trunk diameter was
measured at 10 cm above ground. Three bark thickness measurements were taken after
removing a small square of bark at this same height above ground. A clinometer was
used to calculate height (see Appendix A). Log-transformed data were used in regression
analyses to ensure comparability between species. Microsoft Excel was used to analyze
the significance and strength of relationships between trunk diameter, average bark
thickness and height.
Acacia nigrescens in mesic versus xeric savannas. Allometric data of A. nigrescens
from our study were compared to a similar study undertaken in Matiyani, Mpumalanga
Province, in April 2006 (Bouley et al. unpublished). The Matiyani study measured 35 A.
nigrescens for trunk diameter, bark thickness, and height with methods similar to our
study.
Field Burns
Sample specimens of Acacia nigrescens and Acacia tortilis were burned on the
second and third days of the experiment between the hours of 1000 and 1500. On both
days, the temperature exceeded 35ºC with humidity less than 25%. Due to heavy rain on
the first day of experimentation, trees were surveyed and debarked on the first day and
then burned on the second and third days.
Field burns were implemented using the wick-fire technique (Uhl and Kauffman,
1990). A paraffin-soaked cotton rope was wrapped three times around the trunk and
ignited. All burns were standardized to four minutes. The fires died after roughly two
minutes and were relit with a fresh paraffin-soaked cord. Throughout the four minutes,
the upper canopy was shielded from heat convection. The burned trees were assessed
four days later for visible foliage damage in the form of leaf discoloration and leaf
wilting. An approximate estimation of the percent of canopy cover affected was recorded
as an indictor of the fire damage to the water column.
For the burning experiments, we tested 100 trees in total: 50 A. nigrescens and 50 A.
tortilis. Of the 50 samples, 20 were set aside as controls and the remaining 30 tree
samples were allocated to test either the effects of fire on different stem diameter or the
effects of fire on trees that were debarked.
Burn simulations on different stem diameters. Fifteen samples of A. nigrescens and
15 samples A. tortilis were burned to assess the effects of stem diameter on leaf
discoloration and wilting. The samples of each species were evenly distributed amongst
the three size classes: 20 mm, 25 mm and 30 mm. These samples were not subject to
debarking and were burned as previously outlined.
Effects of bark removal and burning. Twenty samples of A. nigrescens and 20
samples of A. tortilis were treated to varying degrees of bark stripping: 0%, 25%, 50% or
75%. The stem diameter on all samples was 25 mm. The five samples of 25 mm stems
used in the stem diameter experiment were used as the 0% debarked samples. The stems
were stripped in a segment of roughly three centimeters and wicks were wrapped under
the area of debarking so that the flame would directly affect the area stripped. As a
control, an additional 20 specimens of each Acacia sp. were debarked at 0%, 25%, 50%
or 75% but not burned.
